subject: Re: [junit] Message texts
msgSnippet: Sure, In an earlier post Eric suggested: assertTrue( Name field should be valid after entering correct first and last name , nameField.IsValid()); We would
messageBody:
Sure,

In an earlier post Eric suggested:

assertTrue("Name field should be valid after entering correct first
and last name", nameField.IsValid());

We would probably cut it to:
assertTrue("E: Valid Name Field, G: invalid!", nameField.IsValid());

We would rely on the name of the test case to tell us that this was the test of the name entry method.

There was an earlier suggestion of
assertNotNull("Joe has a name", joe.getName());

we would use:

assertNotNull("E: valid name object, G: null", joe.getName());

Our approach is to regularize the output so that we can focus on the cause of the failure rather than deciphering a number of different types of messages. As you point out, this format works well for assertEquals() although we tend to use a lot of assertTrue.

By standardizing our testcase format, and specifying a defined expected result, and loading the actual, this also allows us to reduce many of the asserts to

assertEquals("E: " + expected + " G: " + actual, expected, actual);

of course the same test could be

assertTrue("E: " + expected + " G: " + actual, expected == actual);
or
assertTrue("E: " + expected + " G: " + actual, expected.equals(actual));

depending on the data type.

Since we don't have to think much about the format it allows us to build the tests fairly quickly.


Like any attempt to have a regular format, it can lead to inefficiencies. But we generally feel that the tradeoff is worth it. It also makes it much easier to bring someone new up to speed - they can worry less about the syntax of the failure message and more about the content.


Like I said, we are pretty un-sophisticated, but it seems to work for us.


Jim
